> I was wondering this morning why is it a good lead of self inquiry to ask ourselves what we believe about ourselves, what is the end goal of it.
> I realised that it's because I'm not aware all the time of my believes, I need to load them from my brain, so to speak, to see what they are.
> So, it's the same process I'm doing for every knowledge I have.
> For instance if someone ask me for the capital of a city, I have ask myself the question to get an answer.
> Then, I'm aware of the answer or not depending of the knowledge I have.
> Same if I ask myself why do I, for instance, am afraid of doing something, I can get the answer "because I have social anxiety / lack of confidence / etc", or even no answer at all.

Yes it's great that you noticed this. Your mind is constantly calibrating what you are, including all your likes and dislikes and whatever else. But why does it have to do that? Isn't it redundant if you are always yourself?

> From there, there is absolutely no difference between knowledge and self knowledge. It's same thing.

Yes, that's on the right track.

> But also from there, seems really pointless to use knowledge to know what I am, because it's always gonna be knowledge of a past me.

It's worth questioning, why do you have to think to know what you are? Do your attributes vanish when you stop thinking? Is your perception of that knowledge equivalent to "you"?

I see it as a way of organizing how your attributes affect the world. Figuring out your passions and values is like creating a blueprint for seeing how you can make an impact on the world with your own talent and intelligence. So yeah, that's useful, but it doesnt actually improve or change those attributes that you are mapping out, if that makes sense. You're just organizing those attributes in a certain structure which helps you logically understand it better, so it improves your understanding of those attributes. I don't think it is inherently self-image, but it could become self-image if realizing those attributes caused me to then create more attributes about myself, like "I am intelligent because I value this."
whats the point of believing in something you are experiencing?

Again, it's useful, but it isnt actually intellect or attractiveness or any of those things. You're just imagining how it would affect other things in a successful way, which creates confidence, and you create a gauge like "im more or less attractive" which isnt actually attractiveness, its a relation that you imagine. Don't get me wrong, making the relation is important because it helps you figure out how your attributes affect the world, but that is not actually the attribute itself, it's just what you can do with it.

I experience confidence too, not in my self, but the probability i see in succeeding at something. That is essentially what confidence comes down to. If you're not confident that means you don't believe things are going to go according to plan.

When you say you "believe" in your attractiveness and that makes you confident, that simply means that you are holding your believed attractiveness as your actual attractiveness which you perceive as increasing your success. It doesnt actually make a difference in your attractiveness. Does it help with confidence? maybe, but in the same way that believing that superman will save you from drowning when you decide to swim. Again, there is nothing wrong with having a belief about how your attractiveness is going to relationally affect something else, but the problem becomes when you mistake that relation for the attribute itself, and so you literally turn that attribute into a belief by doing so, thus making that attribute susceptible to other beliefs.

> So the question is then, can I relived the experience of the past with my past eyes?
> Seems not possible.
> I remember there was a period of my life when I was feeling really bad, and thinking about it now does not make me feel this way at all.

You can't relive the past.

You can remember how you looked at things though.

> So by logic the emotions I'm having are not the one from my previous self, but from another source. (should be me now, but still want to take it slow)

Your memory has the potential to create a desire which creates an emotion. Desire and emotion are the same.

For example, you remember something you did, which creates the desire to change what you did in the past, which creates guilt/shame/regret.

If it creates fear, it is perhaps because the memory causes you to imagine a future scenario where you are harmed again by what happens in the memory. Or maybe the fear is because of a genuine belief that you are afflicted by the past scenario, which is a desire to avoid the past scenario. The memory is turned into an object of desire, in this case an object of fear.

> Logically, there's no other way that I can remember event of the past without the emotion I had if it does not occurs now.

I would distinguish recognizing the emotion inside of a memory from actually feeling the emotion. Recognizing emotion in another thing is empathy. I can remember memories and perceive the emotion I had during it, but that is empathy from my perception of the memory.

However, it is also entirely possible for the memory to create emotions. This happens because the memory creates a desire, as mentioned before.

Desires can take up a lot of energy since they create emotions, even the desire to love someone or engage with them. I find the "urge" to cry comes up when you constantly engage with volatile desires and build up tension that way. In the same way that anger "builds up" and explodes if you are mistreated long enough, crying is like the version of that for sadness. It's like the desire to "keep it in" reaches a point where it is biologically impossible because of the stress and tension.

Similar to anger, I find that crying "overrides logic" and causes you to be excessively honest and unfiltered with yourself, which is why it often feels therapeutic (aside from the physical reduction in stress hormones). its actually amazing how intelligent and beneficial even the stereotypically "negative" emotions are when you really observe how they play out

There is no memory during dreaming, but just like an outpouring of thoughts and imagination which may have been influenced by the waking state, so you might be able to say it is "influenced" by memory but not actually memory itself. If memory does occur then it turns into a lucid dream.

Self-image uses thinking and imagination, which I say is made out of the same stuff as dreams, but it is in contrast to the waking state and the memories you have of it. You see self-image as a tool which informs physical survival and existence, but in a dream the entire dream is basically the only reality, whereas self-image is relational to another reality, like a physical one. A dream is self-sustaining but self-image isn't. When it comes to self-image, it's kind of like you have to perceive a physical object or experience first, and then that object or experience causes you to "dream/imagine" about it, which creates self-image. The self-image has to relate itself to that object/experience first, whereas a dream contains the object/experience inside of it and thus it all terminates itself once the dream ends. But self-image doesn't end like that, it pops in and out constantly because it can always "latch on to" or imagine things about physical reality. Imagined self-image acts as a symbol for future or past, but a dream is just a dream, it doesn't symbolize anything aside from itself; you are directly in it and it vanishes once that dream itself stops, there is nothing outside of it.

I would refrain from saying "illusion", I think that creates too many wacky ideas. It's just that your imagination creates distinctions which you falsely extrapolate into existential reality, which is to say, you imagine something that only exists in imagination, but then act as if it exists outside of that medium of imagination.

You feel where the pain is. That feeling does not require any distinguishing or separation. Feeling pain does not claim "my hand is separate from everything else", it's just a feeling, it doesn't make existential claims, your mind does. You point to where the pain is to show the doctor where it is, that pointing is not a distinction either, it is just visual phenomenon from his perspective and your perspective.

Someone poking your leg is a feeling, not separation. You don't experience someone who doesn't experience that, that doesn't occur in your experience, so there is no experienced separation unless you mentally infer it. What happens is that you feel something, you indicate to the other person you felt it, and then they back off. You don't experience their lack of experiencing it. You can only experience things, not a lack of things, unless you imagine that inference.

You say there is a "part of experience"

Which part of experience separates that part from the rest?

Your hand hurting is a feeling, not a distinction. In the same way that feeling sad, happy, or angry, is not a distinction, it is just a feeling with no boundaries. It doesn't say anything existentially about experience, like "since im feeling happy, this is separate, and that is separate, yadda yadda", that is something only your mind can do.

You can experience pain without a glove, and you can experience a glove without pain. You wouldn't say that it "stops being separate" once you stop feeling pain though. This just shows that the pain is not necessary to perceive either thing. 

The feeling of pain is equivalent to what you call "distinguishing", the fact that you feel pain is true. What is not true is that this feeling is actually creating a boundary or separation in experience.
just the entirety of what you are currently perceiving
so the senses are experiences?
Are you currently having two experiences?

If the other person feels the pain too, it doesn't double the experience of your pain, it creates a reaction in that person which tells you "oh he is feeling pain too." That doesn't relinquish any separation, it just creates an imagination about the other person which contains information about them.

Sure, but experientially, where is the separation? Does the separation change once the other person starts experiencing the pain too? Or is it just that you start inferring the other person is feeling pain too?

I'm not talking about like some supernatural shared sense of perception, I am talking about fundamentally what distinctions and separations are "made out of", which is just imagination. It's like how you look at a painting and separate all the objects inside of it, despite it just being one painting.

"I" creates a subject object relationship which you use to conclude that the sensation is "alone." 

If the other person did experience your pain physically somehow, how would that change your experience of the pain? Would it be any different?

I mean that existentially there are no distinctions or boundaries experienced by you, beyond your imagination.

That pain can "be alone" is simply just that you feel alone while feeling pain, which means there is a desire to be with someone else during that pain

Weirdly enough, the pointers in language actually really get tied up with self-image
It's not really theory, he's asking what language actually symbolizes experientially/existentially

> And then I read you and will talk about I and you so what is that from your perspective?

That's language and communication:

https://discord.com/channels/1129343306485215342/1129343306485215345/1204697524196081695

To be more specific, in language, "I" means "my experience." "You" means "your experience." The words make you imagine what my experience is, which is what communication is. In order to communicate you must create "pointers" using words. If I want you to look at a cat, I say "look at the cat", then you imagine a cat to look for, and so you look at the cat in your experience. There are dualities and ownerships which are inherent to language and communication, precisely because the point of communication is not to be accurate, but to communicate. First and foremost, the priority is exchanging ideas with another person using words or "pointers."

As an example, when you say "I love you", that is communicating to the other person "my experience with you is equivalent to love." There is no actual difference between "you" "love" and "I", they are all happening in the same experience, which is yours. And then you are trying to communicate that experience to the other person using relative pointers like "I" "love" "you" because you can only communicate that to them by creating relative pointers. Just saying "my experience" doesn't help them to imagine what your experience is like.

You can't really communicate experience/non-duality "accurately" though. You have to use the words in a "subtractive" way, like you basically say "no, it's not this, it's not that." You have to keep subtracting things.
The ability to communicate with another person through your words is really a profound thing in hindsight.

> Or do you think this is probably unnecessary or not the best approach?

Yeah probably this.

Words are inherently dualistic. Their fundamental job is to communicate your experience to another person, not to accurately describe what you are experiencing. The most accurate communication is just for me to say absolutely nothing, but being accurate doesn't mean you're communicating well. When you say "find an accurate word", my immediate thought is "words are not for being accurate, they are for communicating."

Logic is also dualistic, so words are helpful for untangling people who try to filter their experience through logic. You have to speak their language to communicate with them.

By the way, when I use words, I am using them as any other person would use them. I'm not making up definitions unless I specify.
You're not any thing. There's nothing in experience that can define you because you are experience. Everything you imagine or speak is partial, you can only imagine "things", not "no things."

7 feet tall is a measurement. You can't imagine that you're tall but you can experience it.

> You also think you have characteristics

I don't have to think about something that I am. If you wanna be strict about it, you can't think of a characteristic, you can only think of thoughts.

"I am good at explaining SR" is a communication based on memory and perception of myself.

> That you are saying that your estimation of your skill is not self image. But isn't that I thought about yourself? How is that not self-image? 

It's an estimation, not self-image. Self-image is believing the estimation applies to you.

On the weather app, there is a percentage that predicts rainy weather. It's a prediction/estimation.

Analogously, self-image is like looking at this prediction, and then thinking that you are actually experiencing rainy weather because you are imagining yourself in it.

There's really no technique, you can ask any question to probe further at it.

If there is a sense of "viewing" or "examining" what you think of yourself, then I think a good point of inquiry is: What does it mean to desire something from yourself? How do you desire something in the first place?

You desire things from yourself all the time; something you obtain in the future, a new job opportunity, etc. You imagine yourself in all these situations, and so the situation becomes an object of desire, and then these desires create emotions which are in reaction to the object of desire. How are there two entities, one which desires, and another which is desired from? What are you actually desiring?

I point out desire, because I think it really strikes at the heart of what makes self-image feel "real" and emotional. There can be a sense that "ok I'm just imagining things about me, how silly", but then there is that very visceral counter-thought of "imagining is useful, I need it to survive, the thing I'm imagining is going to actually happen to me at some point" which is really the root of it.

> Why do you think it is like that? Storytelling is a skill, just like drawing, but it is the most heavily influenced art form by our insecurity for some reason. At least that it feels like to me. 

Because it is a communication filtered through their mind. It's their ideas. 

More specifically, with storytelling, it involves building characters who have a certain psychology and mindset. And they have to personally be able to enjoy building those characters. Storytelling is different because it actually involves a lot about psychology and motivation. If you can't reference and include various different psychological perspectives, then the only perspective you can really source is just your own, which can be limited. Like, you have to ask, how does someone who isn't a villain create a villain? And then also, who is to even say what is good or evil? How are you personally going to incorporate that in to the story? You can easily see how the author's personal life experience and psychology intimately ties in to it. I wouldn't say storytelling is that similar to drawing because it literally involves building psychological structures that have to feel realistic and fleshed out and personal. They're both art but very different forms.

On the flip side, I see people watching or reading stories and projecting their own worldviews on it all the time. When it comes to art there is always this type of "projecting" going on, it seems. Like you could have someone watch a story about love and friendship and they'll come out offended like "no that was stupid because the world is a harsh place and you cant rely on love and friendship."

You've probably seen this kind of thing happen before, but someone might even look at your critique and be like "no, that wasn't an insecurity, it was intentional to cleverly point out this aspect of society."

> But if they just call me an idiot, what is attacked? It's the belief I'm not an idiot, or I'm so smart amazing person. But how can a thought be attacked?

It's because your idea of your intelligence is built on a house of cards, so to speak. Because it is literally just an idea, it's not intelligence. To be more specific, what you perceive as your own intelligence is just a reason which motivates you to call yourself intelligent, it is not actually intelligence, it is just a reason to call yourself or describe yourself as that. That is why it is at the risk of other ideas or reasons, like "you are stupid because you did this." If you were perceiving actual intelligence, an idea would not be able to make you doubt it. It's like if you were looking at a lamp and someone was like "that is an elephant." There is nothing to defend or emotionally react to because your experience of the lamp doesn't change because of that statement. 

The intelligence you perceive yourself to "have" is just ownership from the self-image. I talk more about this here:

https://discord.com/channels/1129343306485215342/1129343306485215345/1201017555431727125
https://discord.com/channels/1129343306485215342/1129343306485215345/1199986099158786068

> But how attacked?

When you think of self-image, the thought literally transforms itself into an "object" inside of your experience which the current you tries to avoid. Like imagine if you could conjure up a dangerous snake in your room. And then that snake vanishes when you stop thinking about it. That is what happens with self-image, the thought is literally perceived as a current danger to avoid. The reason for this is because you are perceiving yourself being attacked in that thought, so you think you are genuinely experiencing what you are thinking about and that you need to get away from it somehow.

I think it is literally the exact same mechanism as dreaming, like it's made of the same "stuff", which is just you imagining something and then getting "pulled" into it. But yeah I noticed the exact same thing when observing thoughts, it feels like waking up from a dream when you snap out of it, easier to see in a daydream but also even in normal thoughts that you get emotional about.

This creates a positive emotion because technically the desire is fulfilled. This is also why the "natural state" is always content or happiness, which is a positive emotion.

-Laughter itself is not really an emotion, but it always occurs in tandem with joy or happiness, so you could say the desire is to hear a funny joke, which is fulfilled, and so you become happy. When a desire is fulfilled it is the same as having no desire, because you don't desire something you already have. This point is like a more conceptual way of looking at the previous point, I guess. More fundamentally, the happiness or joy is really just the desire to be in that specific situation and hearing that specific joke, there is no difference between being happy and that situation itself ultimately.
